title: internal compiler error: unexpected panic, when dereferencing a function type

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

body:
I got this error while playing around with Rust:

```
src/core/world.rs:31:10: 31:22 error: type `fn(&core::database::Database, &collections::vec::Vec<collisions::contact::Contact<'_>>)` cannot be dereferenced
src/core/world.rs:31         (*self.solver)(&self.database, &contacts);
                              ^~~~~~~~~~~~
src/core/world.rs:31:9: 31:50 error: the type of this value must be known in this context
src/core/world.rs:31         (*self.solver)(&self.database, &contacts);
                             ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
src/core/world.rs:31:9: 31:50 error: cannot use call notation; the first type parameter for the function trait is neither a tuple nor unit [E0059]
src/core/world.rs:31         (*self.solver)(&self.database, &contacts);
                             ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
error: internal compiler error: unexpected panic
note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.
note: we would appreciate a bug report: http://doc.rust-lang.org/complement-bugreport.html
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` for a backtrace
task 'rustc' panicked at 'index out of bounds: the len is 1 but the index is 1', /Users/rustbuild/src/rust-buildbot/slave/nightly-mac/build/src/librustc/middle/typeck/check/mod.rs:2
608
```

I ran into this problem on my Mac OS X (i386), the output from `rustc --version=verbose`:

```
rustc 0.13.0-nightly (88b6e93d3 2014-10-31 23:36:48 +0000)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 88b6e93d35c34e143ba060a617e71c8af10fa15e
commit-date: 2014-10-31 23:36:48 +0000
host: x86_64-apple-darwin
release: 0.13.0-nightly
```

If it helps, this is the offending file:

```
use core::Database; // struct { }
use solvers::ForceSolver; // struct { }
use collisions::BroadPhase; // fn(&Database, &Vec<Contact>);
use integrators::StateIntegrator; // fn(&mut Body, f32);

pub struct World<BP: BroadPhase> {
    database: Database,
    broadphase: BP,
    solver: ForceSolver,
    integrator: StateIntegrator,
}

impl<BP: BroadPhase> World<BP> {
    pub fn new(broadphase: BP, solver: ForceSolver, integrator: StateIntegrator) -> World<BP> {
        World{
            database: Database::new(),
            broadphase: broadphase,
            solver: solver,
            integrator: integrator,
        }
    }

    pub fn update(&mut self, time_step: f32) {
        let mut contacts = Vec::new();

        self.broadphase.reindex(&self.database);
        self.broadphase.each_contact(&self.database, |contact| contacts.push(contact));

        (*self.solver)(&self.database, &contacts);
        self.database.each_body_mut(|body| self.integrator(body, time_step));
    }
}
```

My understanding of Rust isn’t great, so chances are it is an error in my code, though I don’t think that should have lead to a compiler bug. Let me know if you need more information.
